When should I start worrying about domains

responses:
Until stage 2, we recommend not worrying about domains but just follow whatever interests you most. If you ever get sick of a domain, feel free to stray or widen the domain.

Domains are not hard-coded things, but just a concept we created to help section of the language. Anything could be a domain. Anime would be a very wide domain. Drama, horror, fantasy could all be domains but also somewhat broad. Slice of life is a common first domain as it generally deals with the common language used in everyday speech. High school stories with girl protagonists that take place in Tokyo would be a somewhat small domain. The more narrow your domain, the faster you will feel comfortable in it, and the quicker you will reach that level 4 level 5 comprehension ideal for immersion. But also, the more potential there is for becoming sick of the content. So really balancing this is up to you. How small can you make a domain to make good progress, compared to how motivated can you stay.

As always, remember to prioritize motivation and interest. You will still make progress even if you never stick to a domain. It will just be slower. But slower, enjoyable progress is always better than quicker agonizing progress. And in reality, the fact that you don't enjoy the content anymore will most likely make the more efficient path actually take longer and become less efficient, so don't force a domain too much.

Comprehension levels are a device Refold created to communicate how well we are comprehending our content. The stages in Refold are generally all based on comprehension, as we feel it's the most crucial part of language learning. With understanding, speaking and output follow naturally. The articles linked below go into more detail about comprehension levels.

patterns: Why is enjoying the language important
Why is there emphasis on enjoyment
responses: This is twofold. First, learning Japanese is a very long process. It will take years before you are ready to start speaking even. The more you enjoy your immersion and time with the language, the more likely you will stick with this very long process. On top of that, language acquisition benefits from focus and engagement. So being into the story, being into your immersion, enjoying your time will actually help speed up the process, and you will be able to remain more focused for longer. Your brain will pin importance on what it's watching and go to work in the background.

patterns: What does it mean to Tolerate Ambiguity
why is tolerating ambiguity so important
why do you put such importance on tolerating ambiguity
responses: Tolerating ambiguity is the acceptance that you won't understand everything. And not only that, but early on, you won't understand A LOT. You must be okay with this. Refold works on finding low-hanging fruit. Hunting down elements of the language that are within your grasp to obtain and understand. To do this, you have to sift through a lot of stuff that is NOT within your range. If you waste time trying to grasp these concepts and understand everything, you will drastically slow down your progress. By accepting ambiguity and being okay with not understanding, you maximize your gains in the language. I've linked an article and a video down below that further explains the importance of accepting ambiguity. This is a crucial concept to understand. I recommend going through both these resources.
This is the act of transitioning from using the bilingual dictionary to using a monolingual dictionary. I recommend checking out the resources I've linked below for more info.

patterns: When should I do the Monolingual Transition
when is it recomended to do the monolingual transition
responses: This is up to you. Refold recommends doing it in stage 2B or 2C. However, you can do it earlier or later. The earlier you do it, the sooner you reap the positive benefits, but the more frustrating it will be. And it CAN be frustrating, that is for sure. The longer you wait, the easier it will be, but you will benefit from its benefits later. In the end, as soon as you are motivated and excited to make the transition, go for it. Even if you start and get sick of it, you can take a break and postpone the rest for later.

Comprehensible input is the idea that you can understand. It's capable of being understood. While finding comprehensible input that you are interested in is great, it can sometimes be challenging. We don't recommend spending more than a handful of minutes looking for your next piece of content. Hunting for content within your range can sometimes be a big waste of time. If you have some stuff you feel is in your range, go for it, but Refold focuses on finding little chunks of comprehensible input. Sentences here and there. Words here and there. Focus more on finding the content you are interested in and engaged by more so than content in your range. For some people, that interest comes from being comprehensible. For others, it comes from following a subject. Whatever works for you, try and follow it, but don't procrastinate too much by overhunting that perfect piece of content. Volume is essential with immersion. We want A LOT of it.
No, Refold can be used for any language where native content is obtainable.

how do I know immersion works
how do we know immersion works
what is the proof refold works
responses: The core, the foundation of Refold, is immersion learning. Thousands of people and tons of data are proof that immersion learning works. Dr. Stephen Krashen has spent his life promoting the Input Hypothesis. The foundation for all immersion learning methods. While Refold searches to find the best way to apply these language acquisition principles in an easy-to-follow, step by steep process, in the end, it all comes down to immersion. Matt, the creator of Refold, has used immersion to reach incredibly high levels in Japanese, along with thousands of others. If Immersion works is not the question. The question is, how much more can we streamline the process.

patterns: How many domains should I know
How many domains do I need to know
How many domains should I master
responses: Life is made up of domains. You will need to know however many domains you feel you need to know to live and function in the life you want. That being said, we recommend focusing on 1 somewhat narrow domain at a time, especially early on, to help speed up your progress. Getting more exposure to similar vocab and concepts will accelerate the rate at which you acquire those ideas fully. So focusing in on a narrow domain will help that happen.

patterns: What domain should I try first
what domain should I do first
responses: We generally recommend people do a Slice of Life domain first. Slice of life content typically has vocabulary and speech patterns that more closely resemble everyday speech, so we find it a beneficial first domain. But with that said, never force content. If it is messing with your motivation, find whatever domain works for you.

Stage 2C, other than Stage 4, which is ongoing, is generally by far the longest stage in Refold. This is where you take your comprehension in your first domain from comprehension level 3 up to comprehension 5 or 6. There is a lot of vocabulary, phrases, sentence structures, and more in between you and the end of this stage, so it takes a long time. On top of that, you are learning increasingly less common vocabulary, so you will come across each word you learn less and less often. This can make progress feel non-existent even though, in actuality, you are continuing to make significant progress. It can take years, depending on you and your time invested. Patience is the key to making it through this stage, but know you are not alone. Everyone has to trudge through this desert, and the oasis at the end will be all that more satisfying because of the challenge. Sadly there is not trick to make this stage faster other than, just immerse more.

patterns: How small should a domain be
how much you should shrink your domain
how much should you shrink your domain
how narrow should my domain be
responses: This is kind of up to you. The more narrow your domain, the more likely you will come across the same vocabulary and elements to fully acquire them. However, you also want to make sure you stay motivated and engaged in your immersion rather than mindlessly board with an extremely narrow domain. You will need to find this balance for yourself. In the end, as long as you are spending focused, quality time with the language, you WILL learn it. So don't stress too much about having the perfect domain size. Just have it on your mind and try your best.

The **snowball effect** is basically the idea that new elements generally become easier to learn and understand as you know more and more of the language. This is because you now have solidified knowledge and memories to attach and relate new info to.

I have linked a video below that covers the **snowball effect** as well as **low hanging fruit** and how this applies to leeches in Anki. While the video covers leeches, this concept applies to many elements of the Refold method and why we make the recommendations.

responses: 1T (or i+1) sentence, is short for 1 target sentence. It is a concept you don't need to worry about till you start sentence mining in stage 2. It basically is a perfect sentence where you understand everything but 1 element. We hunt these sentences down to slowly chip away, learning new vocabulary in context that we understand once we look up that 1 new element. I've linked a refold article below talking about it, but I would not worry about it too much till you are ready to start sentence mining.
